coredata.dc:title: Application of the EXAFS method to Jahn—Teller ions: static and dynamic behavior of Cu(H2O)6 2+ and Ci(H2O)2+ 6 in aqueous solution
coredata.dc:creator: Sham, T.K.
Hastings, J.B.
Perlman, M.L.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
EXAFS measurements have been made on the octahedral Jahn—Teller complexes, Cu(H2O)6 2+ and Cr(H2O)6 2+, in aqueous solution. Two distinct metal—oxygen bond lengths are not clearly resolvable in the EXAFS Fourier transforms for each species; lengths and Deuye—Waller factors obtained suggest that the axial ligands are loosely bonded.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 83, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 October 1981 APPLICATION OF THE EXAFS METHOD TO JAHN-TELLER IONS: STATIC AND DYNAMIC BEHAVIOR OF Cu(H^O)^ AND Cr^O)^ IN AQUEOUS SOLUTION * TJC. SHAM, J.B. HASTINGS and M.L. PERLMAN Chemistry Department. Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York, New York 11973. USA Received 4 April 1981 EXAFS measurements have been made on the octahedral Jahn—Teller complexes, CuCHaO)!*" and CrffIzO)!*", in aque- ous solution- Two distinct metal—oxygen bond lengths are not clearly resolvable in the EXAFS Fourier transforms for each species; lengths and Debye—Waller factors obtained suggest that the axial iigands are loosely bonded. It is well established that the environment of the metal ion in six coordinate Cu2"1' and Cr2"1' complexes is tetragonaUy distorted [1,2] m the solid and similar hexaaquo complexes, Cu(H20)|"1" and Cr^^O)24", are believed to form m solution [3]. This non-sphen- cal symmetry, known as a Jahn—Teller distortion [4—6], arises from the removal of some degeneracy of electrons m the d^ and d4 states of the ions in the molecular field. We have recorded EXAFS (extended X-ray absorption fine structure) spectra of Cu2"*" and Cr24' ions m aqueous solution with two objectives in mind: (1) to examine the applicability of the EXAFS technique m the measurement of the distances m these structures, because, although a number of Jahn— Teller Cu complexes have been studied with EXAFS [7—9], the axial (elongated) bonds have not been "seen"; (2) to study the static and dynamic character- istics of these Jahn—Teller complexes in solution in order to better understand the kinetics and mechanism of the H^O-exchange reaction [3] M^O)^ + H,0 * ^ MO^G^^O*)24^ + HzO, (1) where water molecules originally in the bulk are label- led H^O * to mdicate the exchange. * A preliminary account of this worfc -was presented at the 178th National Meeting of the American Chemical Society, Washington, D.C., Sept 1979. EXAFS * refers to the oscillation of the X-ray ab- sorption coefficient of an element above its character- istic threshold (Ey), which arises from interference be- tween the outgoing and the backscattered photoelec- tron waves. Since the outgoing wave is backscattered primarily by atoms m the immediate vicinity of the absorbing atom, the EXAFS pattern of a particular absorbing atom in a molecule depends upon the inter- atomic distances and the rigidity of the bonds between the absorbing and the scattering atoms, as well as their scattering amplitudes. In a two-distance system with four short equatorial and two long axial bonds between the absorbing atom and its neighbors, the EXAFS function \(k) can be expressed as X(&) = (ti -Po)lHo = -[14/(ir, fc)l/fo-iq] X exp(- 2o2q fc2) sin[2fo-eq + W] (2) where p. is the absorption coefficient, fty is the free- atom absorption coefficient, k is the photoelectron wave vector (k = [2m(E - Ey)] 1/2//!, with£" the pho- ton energy), the coefficients 4 and 2 are the coordina- * The technique is now well established for simple systems, for a review see refs- [10.111- 391 Volume 83, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 October 1981 ion numbers,/(TT, k) is the backscattenng amplitude, F2 is the mean-square deviation of r in the harmonic ipproxunation, X is the electron mean free path exp(—2r,/X) is ^1 for short distances), and 0(fc) is a )hase function characteristic of the absorbing and icattenng pair It appears from eq. (2) that r^y and r^ should ap- aear as "peaks"++ in the Fourier transform of x(k)k" md should be extracted easily, provided 0(fc) is 1m- sar m k. We shall examine the reliability of this meth- od with simulated EXAFS spectra for several values if A/-=r,—7-gQ. A complete analysis [10.11] of the lata involves fitting the Fourier filtered data to eq (2) vith 0(A-) and/(7r, k) functions obtained from either nodel compounds or theory. Theoretical functions [12,13] are used in the present work. EXAFS experiments were earned out at the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory. Perchlo- •ate solutions of^l M were prepared with precaution igamst hydrolysis a few days prior to the experiment md kept m an inert atmosphere before and during he run as described previously[14,15]. The Fourier transform of\(k)k2 ++ for Cu^O)^ and the best fit * Of two distances 10 the filtered data are shown TI fig. 1. Parameters from the fit in fig. 1 and rele- vant parameters for other MO-I^O)!"1' complexes are listed in table 1. It is interesting to see in fig. la that there is an intense peak at 1.48 A and a weak peak at 2 A. If the weak peak can with confidence be identi- fied as that for the axial distance r^, the difference in peak positions gives us Ar (assuming <?(Ar) is linear 1" The peak position in the Founer transform is r = r — a, where a is a constant for a given system provided that 0(t) is linear m k, see ref [12]. ''r The background must be subtracted and the data norma- lized to obtain the EXAFS curve (k) It is always helpful to •» eight the curve v-ithk". where n = 1— 3 depending on the k dependence of the scattering amplitude function of the scatterer. k = 2 is an optimum choice for oxygen. Four sections are used in background subtraction, see ref. [10]. * Since the phoioelectron excitation is in general a many-body process (Shakf-up, Shake-off), the experimental amplitude function is always smaller than the theoretical function (60 ± 20% of theory). A scale factor, S, is commonly em- ployed in the fitting m such a way that S A(fc)theory = •'4 (^experiment' where S should always be less than unity. For heavy scatters, nonhneanty becomes important and S becomes a function of k. For detailed discussion see ref. [16]. Fig 1- (a) Founer transform of x(fc)fc2 for Cu(H20)i*". (b) Fourier filtered data ( — ) and the best fit, (———) = fc^Weq and(—-)=&2x(fc)a.x- m k) [12]. However, we must be careful because the length of the data set here is limited [16] ** (the k range is ="3—13 A-1). This, together with the^V,/r2 (N[ = coordination number) dependence of the over- all amplitude, the variation m a, the k dependence of f(Tt, k) [10,11] and noise in the experimental data can produce misleading features in this 1.5—2.0 A region, in r space. In order to see the effects of these variables, we have simulated EXAFS spectra of Cu^^O)^ with eq. (2), using theoretical phase and amplitude functions, several values for Ar and the a, and the same length in k space as the experimental data. The Fourier transforms of these spectra are shown m fig. 2. Several features are apparent. First, ** The Shorter the data length, the poorer the resolution in r space, on the other hand, the higher the k value, the worse the signal-to-noise ratio. 392 Table 1 EXAFS structurala) parameters and kinetic l>) data for M(H2 0)"'*' (n = 2.3) Aquo ions c) /M"+ (A) rCM-HaO) (A) d) a W e) *1 (S-1) Oi(H20)r 0.72 eq 1.955(1.94-2.15) 0.036 ax 2 60(2.38-2.50) 0.12 8X 109 Cr(H20)J* 0.80 eq 1.985 0.036 ax 2.30 0.15 7X 109 Cr(H20)r 0.65 1.966(1.98) 0.065 5X 10"7 MnaizOJr FeCHaO)^ FeWaO)^ Co(H20)'T 0.91 0.83 067 082 2.177(2 20) 2.095(2.12) 1.990(1.99) (208) 0.078 0.081 0.055 3X 107 3X 106 3X 103 1 X 106 NiCHzOr 0.78 2.05(2.04-2.06) 0 — 3X 104 a) Best values from the fit. b) From ref. (g)-(k) Similar simulations with 01 = 0.04 A and a-i = 0.12 A. ^lume 83, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 October 1981 nere are satellite structures at both sides of the main ieak. These are related to the data length and to the iature of the absorbing and scattering atoms (Cu and )); for example, the one-distance spectrum. Fig. 2a, learly shows systematic ringing at the higher r side, Mth the first peak at =e2 A having 19% the height of hai of the main peak. Second, the position correspon- Lmg to a second simulated Cu—0 distance cannot be ;learly identified because of the ringing and poor res- ilution in r space [16]. Finally, the only parameter ensiuve to AT and o is the amplitude of the main ieak. there is an amplitude minimum as i\r varies. fhis last observation has some subtle implications to he amplitude analysis [16] and will be discussed isewhere. It is clear that the Fourier transform technique Jone is not always adequate *** to extract two dis- ances in a case such as this and must be used with 'aution. It should be noted that the Fourier transform )f\(fc)A:2 for CuCH^O)!"1' m fig. la was filtered with [ rather large window to minimize distortion. Further o explore the analysis, the filtered data were fitted to wo-distance and one-distance curves. Fig. 3a shows he sum of the two contributions from fig. Ib (dashed) md the filtered, back-transformed experimental data solid). With a single distance, the best fit to these lata is that shown m fig. 3b. With two distances, the it especially at low k, is better than with one, and ndeed the longer axial bonds must make their most mponant contribution at low k. as may be seen in ig. Ib. The simulated one-disiance data of fig. 2a are hown backtransformed m fig 3c (solid) together with i fit for two distances, one equal to the value simu- ated and a second corresponding to r^ (dashed). Mismatch m the low k region is apparent. We conclude hat there are probably two distances, albeit the un- '** We have recorded EXAFS spectra of a series ofCu-0, Cu—N, and Cu—Cl complexes in the solid state at both room. and liquid nitrogen temperatures and find that only m rather covalent systems having short rgq, r^ and small o can Ar be clearly identified in thepourier trans- forms. Details will be given m a forthcoming publication [17]. Fig. 3. Best fit of one- and two-distances to the backtrans- formed filtered experimental data and to computer simulated data. (a) /eq = 1.955, oeq = 0.036, /-ax = 2.60, dax = 0.12 (dashes), experimental data (solid), (b) r = 1.959, a = 0.039 (dashes); experimental data (solid), (c) /-eq = 134, oeq = 0 04, ''ax = 2.60, oax = 0.12 (dashes); computer simulated data (solid). Distances quoted for (a), (b), and (c) are all in A. (94 Volume 83, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 October 1981 certainty associated with the second distance is largettt, consistent with X-ray scattering measurements [18]. Despite the large uncertainties in the Og^ values, the a do provide important information. With a^ ^ 0.12 A, at room temperature, we can delineate the following situations: either an extremely weak axial bond (with a rather small force constant compared to that for the totally symmetric stretching of the equatorial M—H^O bond, vide infra) or static disorder due to nonbonduig but highly polarized H^O mole- cules in the axial direction. In either case, it would not be totally unreasonable to consider these complexes m solution as being essentially planar. Returning to eq. (1), this exchange reaction in- volves the substitution of a coordinated water mole- cule by solvent water. In other words, reactants and products are identical. It is well known [3,19] that the SNii mechanism for substitution reactions (fig. 4a) prevails among first row transition metal M-^^ com- plexes and that the reaction rate generally decreases with decrease in ionic radius. Cu^H^O^and Ci^H^O)!"*" are exceptions. These ions, despite their small ionic radii [19], have the fastest rates (table 1), an anomaly attributed to the easy leaving of the loosely bonded axial ugands [3]. Von Eigen [19] has proposed an inversion mechanism through which the equatorial bgands become axial and participate in fast exchange. This process involves compression of the two axial bonds and stretching of either pair of opposite equatorial bonds (figs. 4b, 4c). Thus, the bond distances and the associated Debye—Waller fac- tors from EXAFS measurements are very useful for consideration of these very fast reactions. It is interesting first to compare the r and a EXAFS results for (^(H^O)24" and Ci^H^O)24' with those for other M^^O)24^ complexes (table 1). It must be noted thatthe M—OH^ distance is not necessarily re- lated to the ionic radius linearly because the effects of crystal field stabilization and polarization have been included in the former. It appears, in table 1, ++t Different truncations of the data and k3 weighting show that the uncertainty m r^x results is at least ±0.05 A and that in oax is ±0.2 A. Since f(n, k) of oxygen falls off rapidly at higher k, an insufficient background subtrac- tion would affect the axial parameters tremendously. Finally, only low k data contain significant information for Fax; but part of the low * data must to be truncated to minimize the varying multielectron effects on the EXAFS spectra. Fig. 4. Inversion process for Jahn—Teller distorted complexes, CuCHzO)!4" and CrCHaO)^ in solution; the solid circles are the axial Ugands (after von Eigen, ref. [19]; (a) axial substi- tution, (b) and (c) inversion. that among M24" ions the longer the M—OH^ distance, the larger the a and the faster the exchange rate. This suggests that the fast exchange rates measured for Cr24" and Cu24" occur at the axial positions and that the involvement of the rather tightly bonded equato- rial ugands m direct exchange at room temperature is negligible. We next consider the relationship of the EXAFS results to the inversion process proposed to be occur- ring very rapidly at room temperature aslO"11 s[6]. If the inversion occurs on the vibrational time scale, we should see two short bonds with small vibrational amplitude and four long bonds with large amplitude-. 0 The long bonds should have the equilibrium bond length of the transition state Le. <s2.3 A. The corresponding o- should also be large, •=0.2—0.3 A. In this case, the inversion itself is a molecular vibration mode. 395 /olume 83, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 October 1981 [Tiis is obviously not the case. Therefore the inversion nust occur on a time scale considerably slower. Be- ;ause of the large difference between the axial and equa- :onal bond lengths, it is reasonable to assume that the ;nergy required for the inversion is large Further, the T parameter for the equatorial bonds is small We re- ;aU that o2 = a^ + a^ -a^. Here a^, a^ 7" L are the mean-square deviations of the equihbn- im distances resulting from all molecular vibration nodes, static disorder, and mnersphere—outersphere •xchange [14]. Considering the displacement ampli- ude of the totally symmetric stretching vibration 20] ofCu(H20)4S04 (v.y^ = 440 cm-1) [21] 7^ = (h/S^n^y^) coth(hv/2kr) , (3) vhere fi^ is the reduced mass [20], we obtain a^ym ; 0.026 A, not too far from the observed a = 0.036 A. [Tiese results, considered together with the rather hort Cu—O-I^O) equatorial distance, indicate thai he inversion does not occur concertedly via ground »r lower excited state molecular vibrations. This con- tusion, however, does not eliminate the possible oc- :urrence of inversion m highly excited states on a lower time scale In summary, we have reported EXAFS results of arm-Teller complexes CuCH^O)^ and Cr(H:,0)g1" n solution. Our careful analysis indicates tha; there re two distances m these complexes albeit the axial igands are at best loosely bonded. EXAFS bond engths and Debye—Waller factors are employed to :onsider the substitution reaction involving coordi- lated H^O and H^O in solution. The result shows hat only axial substitution is important and that ixial—equatorial inversion cannot occur via low ex- ited state vibrations We thank Drs. B. Brunschwig, M Newton and N. iutm for discussions and M. Chou for preparing some amples. Considering the displacement ampli- ude of the totally symmetric stretching vibration 20] ofCu(H20)4S04 (v.y^ = 440 cm-1) [21] 7^ = (h/S^n^y^) coth(hv/2kr) , (3) vhere fi^ is the reduced mass [20], we obtain a^ym ; 0.026 A, not too far from the observed a = 0.036 A. head.ce:title: Application of the EXAFS method to Jahn—Teller ions: static and dynamic behavior of Cu(H2O)6 2+ and Ci(H2O)2+ 6 in aqueous solution

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Chemistry Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York, New York 11973, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: EXAFS measurements have been made on the octahedral Jahn—Teller complexes, Cu(H2O)6 2+ and Cr(H2O)6 2+, in aqueous solution. Two distinct metal—oxygen bond lengths are not clearly resolvable in the EXAFS Fourier transforms for each species; lengths and Deuye—Waller factors obtained suggest that the axial ligands are loosely bonded.
